title: 112_s342
content: The Act is titled the "Republic of the Marshall Islands Supplemental Nuclear Compensation Act of 2011" and includes provisions for continued monitoring on Runit Island. Section 103(f)(1) of the Compact of Free Association Amendments Act of 2003 is amended to include continued monitoring on Runit Island, specifically focusing on the Cactus Crater containment and groundwater. The Secretary of Energy will conduct visual studies every 4 years starting from January 1, 2008. The Secretary of Energy will conduct visual surveys every 4 years on the concrete exterior of the Cactus Crater containment structure and perform radiochemical analysis of the groundwater on Runit Island. A report will be submitted to the Senate and House committees detailing the survey results. The Secretary of Energy will conduct visual surveys and radiochemical analysis to determine any health risks from contaminants in the Cactus Crater containment structure on Enewetak. Funding for groundwater monitoring will be provided by the Secretary of the Interior. The Department of Energy, Marshall Islands Program, will receive funds from the Office of Insular Affairs for radiochemical analysis of groundwater. SEC. 3. CLARIFICATION OF ELIGIBILITY UNDER ENERGY EMPLOYEES OCCUPATIONAL ILLNESS COMPENSATION PROGRAM ACT OF 2000. The Energy Employees Occupational Illness Compensation Program Act of 2000 is amended to include citizens or nationals of the Republic of the Marshall Islands or the Federated States of Micronesia as covered employees and Department of Energy contractor employees. The Energy Employees Occupational Illness Compensation Program Act of 2000 is amended to include citizens or nationals of the Republic of the Marshall Islands or the Federated States of Micronesia as covered employees and Department of Energy contractor employees, with benefits offset in relation to the Compact of Free Association. The Energy Employees Occupational Illness Compensation Program Act of 2000 is amended to include citizens or nationals of the Republic of the Marshall Islands or the Federated States of Micronesia as covered employees and Department of Energy contractor employees. Individuals awarded compensation under this title will have their benefits offset by any compensation received under the Compact of Free Association, except for medical and vocational rehabilitation benefits. Section 103(h) of the Compact of Free Association Amendments Act of 2003 is amended to include an annual supplemental health care grant for the Republic of the Marshall Islands, focusing on enhanced primary health care and regular screenings for radiogenic illnesses. The Compact of Free Association Amendments Act of 2003 includes a supplemental health care grant for the Marshall Islands to improve primary health care, conduct regular screenings for radiogenic illnesses, and provide medical field team visits to atolls affected by US nuclear testing. Additionally, it aims to enhance the Marshall Islands' capabilities for treating radiogenic illness and establish a whole-body counting facility on Utrik Atoll. Conditions on grant funds usage will be overseen by the Secretary of the Interior in consultation with the Marshall Islands. The Compact of Free Association Amendments Act of 2003 provides a health care grant for the Marshall Islands to improve primary health care and establish a whole-body counting facility on Utrik Atoll. The Secretary of the Interior, in consultation with the Marshall Islands, may establish additional conditions on the grants. A memorandum of agreement will be entered into by the Secretary of the Interior, the Secretary of Energy, and the Government of the Marshall Islands to outline responsibilities. $4,500,000 is appropriated to the Secretary of the Interior for this purpose. $4,500,000 is appropriated for fiscal years 2009 through 2023, adjusted for inflation, to carry out health care grants for the Marshall Islands as outlined in the Compact of Free Association Amendments Act of 2003. The Secretary of the Interior will have the National Academy of Sciences assess the health impacts of the US nuclear testing program in the Marshall Islands. A report will be submitted to Congress upon completion. Authorization of appropriations is provided for this assessment.
